headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Celebrities Face Legal Exposure After Collapse Of Crypto Giant; Financial Expert Suze Orman Joins CNN THIS MORNING; "ELLEN" Show's Stephen 'Twitch' Boss Dead By Suicide At 40. Aired 7:30-8a ET

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Got it.

utterances.speaker: ZAIN ASHER, CNN INTERNATIONAL ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: I have to say, though, the line -- the line that got me the most -- the line that made me emotional is when she said look, this is not my country. I have tried so hard to fit in and it's simply not good enough.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ASHER
utterances.sentences: Every Black, British person understands exactly what she meant by that statement --

utterances.speaker: TRISHA GODDARD, CNN CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: To some, yes.

utterances.speaker: ASHER
utterances.sentences: -- because we've all been there.

utterances.speaker: GODDARD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ASHER
utterances.sentences: We know what that is.

utterances.speaker: GODDARD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ASHER
utterances.sentences: You know, to be bullied -- anyone who has been to high school understands that to be bullied in this world, generally there's two ingredients. There's two things that make a person more vulnerable for bullying, and that is if they are different --

utterances.speaker: GODDARD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ASHER
utterances.sentences: -- and if they are vulnerable.She's obviously different because she's Black. She's vulnerable because nobody had her back. Apart from Doria, nobody. Not her family, not her husband's family. And, oh -- I mean --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I understand the racism here, but in Britain it is deep.

utterances.speaker: ASHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It is deep.We've got to run, though.

utterances.speaker: GODDARD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Thank you all three so much. It was a really great conversation.

utterances.speaker: MEINZER
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GODDARD
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right. Some celebrities here in the United States are facing big lawsuits over their promotion of cryptocurrency. We'll tell you what kind of exposure they may be facing.

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Plus, tips on how to protect your money -- your assets -- there she is -- in this uncertain economy. Financial expert guru Suze Orman is here.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Hi, Suze.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Good morning, everyone, and welcome back to CNN THIS MORNING.The conversation about mental health in America after the suicide of Stephen 'Twitch' Boss -- we'll talk about that. Plus, frustration is boiling at the border as officials brace for a surge of migrants in the coming week. And we're going to dive into the so-called Twitter files. What facts -- what is fact and what is fiction.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Also this morning, the FTX debacle and downfall has brought a renewed focus on celebrities who have endorsed and touted crypto. Tom Brady, Jimmy Fallon, Madonna, David Ortiz -- just some of the rich and famous that are facing lawsuits from investors now, with plaintiffs claiming they did not properly disclose their own involvement with the digital financial institutions.CNN's Christine Romans joins us now. Are they facing real legal exposure? CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNN CHIEF BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT, ANCHOR, "EARLY START":  You know, look, the A-list there -- they're out hunting for lawyers and using the lawyers they already have because sports celebrities and sports figures are finding out that those high-profile crypto endorsements that they hyped are bringing costly lawsuits. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Disgraced FTX founder and former CEO Sam Bankman-Fried is in jail, accused of carrying out what a prosecutor called one of the biggest financial frauds in American history.Bankman-Fried earned the backing of prominent figures across Hollywood, sports, and politics.

utterances.speaker: TOM BRADY, QUARTERBACK, TAMPA BAY BUCCANEERS
utterances.sentences: I'm getting into crypto.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: With FTX -- you're in?

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Now, several celebrities who endorsed cryptocurrency are all under fresh legal scrutiny, including 7-time Super Bowl champion Tom Brady, supermodel Gisele Bundchen, and 4-time NBA champion Steph Curry.They're among some named in a class action lawsuit filing against Bankman-Fried last month after his company suffered a liquidity crisis, collapsed, and filed for bankruptcy. At least a million people can't access their funds. He is denying defrauding customers. The lawsuit alleges they did not properly disclose the scope and amount of compensation they personally received in exchange for the promotion of FTX. One of the plaintiffs in the proposed class action suit, Michael Livieratos, says, "As a New England Patriots fan my entire life, you can imagine the influence that Tom Brady would have," claiming he moved nearly all his money from another crypto exchange to FTX. Adam Moskowitz, the lawyer representing the plaintiffs, told The Washington Post "You have very rich people we all love telling us that they checked this out and it was okay. Why shouldn't they be held responsible?" This is just the tip of the iceberg for the crypto fallout. Another lawsuit was filed earlier this month by cryptocurrency investors against the NFT series Bored Ape Yacht Club. JIMMY FALLON, HOST, "THE TONIGHT SHOW STARRING JIMMY FALLON":  We're part of the same -- we're part of the same community.

utterances.speaker: PARIS HILTON, MEDIA PERSONALITY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FALLON
utterances.sentences: We're both apes.

utterances.speaker: HILTON
utterances.sentences: Yes. I love it.ROMANS (voice-over):  In the complaint, 37 defendants are named, including Paris Hilton, Jimmy Fallon, Justin Bieber, Madonna, Serene Williams, and again, Steph Curry. The lawsuit accuses the creators of enlisting A-listers to mislead their followers into buying bad investments at inflated prices. Actor Ben McKenzie testified before the Senate Banking Committee Wednesday, describing crypto as a bill of goods sold to tens of millions of Americans.

utterances.speaker: BEN MCKENZIE, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: They have been lied to in ways both big and small, by a once seemingly mighty crypto industry whose entire existence, in fact, depends on misinformation, hype, and yes, fraud.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: So, none of the celebrities named in these lawsuits responded to CNN's request for comment, you guys.Another crypto lawsuit against EthereumMax was dismissed recently after the judge said that it wasn't clear the investors who sued actually saw the promotions. Kim Kardashian and Floyd Mayweather Jr. were named in that one. Kardashian, by the way, paid more than a million dollars in October to settle with the SEC over failing to disclose that she was paid to promote a crypto token on Instagram. She was paid $250,000 to promote a token on Instagram -- something that was not disclosed. She settled quickly with the SEC over that.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Big questions for all of these celebrities.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: A lot more fallout, I'm sure.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: All right. The Federal Reserve raised rates again by half a point yesterday. This follows months of much higher increases to the Fed -- to the Fed's fight on inflation. But higher interest rates from the Fed means higher interest rates for you on loans, on credit cards, and a lot more.Jerome Powell, the Fed chair, warned there is a long way to go until we see normal inflation. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JEROME POWELL, CHAIRMAN, FEDERAL RESERVE
utterances.sentences: It's good to see progress, but let's just understand we have a long ways to go to get back to price stability.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Whoo.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you, thank you.And who is right? Who is right? SUZE ORMAN, FINANCIAL EXPERT, HOST, "WOMEN & MONEY (AND EVERYONE SMART ENOUGH TO LISTEN)" PODCAST, CO-FOUNDER, SECURESAVE.COM (via Webex by Cisco):  Well listen, it's -- you can have all these people on television saying everything's great -- but just look, truthfully, at your next door neighbor, at the people on the streets. The people that I talk to, Poppy, that call in or that write in to the podcast. They don't have the money to pay their bills. Many of them are living paychecks to paychecks. They can't afford their rent. Good luck if they're ever going to be able to afford a house at these prices, and the cost of food. So, I have -- I just think we're in far greater trouble than everybody wants us to believe that we're in.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You do?So listen to this, Suze. The CEO of United Airlines, Scott Kirby, was on with us a few days ago. Here's what he said.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SCOTT KIRBY, CEO, UNITED AIRLINES
utterances.sentences: If I didn't watch business shows or read The Wall Street Journal, the word recession wouldn't be in my vocabulary because we just don't see it in our data.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But you see it from normal folks?

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Of course, you don't see it in your data because you're also not seeing where are the people who are getting those tickets to fly on your airlines. Where does that money come from? Now, maybe the people aren't delinquent yet on their credit cards but they are paying this on their credit cards. Most people in the United States don't have an emergency savingsaccount of more than a few bucks if anything. You know, most people can't even afford $400 for an emergency. So, there are people who are absolutely flying, who are going out to eat, who are going to hotels. But in my opinion, they're putting that on their credit cards. And they're doing it because of why? They had so much in savings during the pandemic because we subsidized them in every possible way. They didn't have to pay their mortgages. They didn't have to pay their student loan. They didn't have to do anything. And yet, they were getting all of this money. Now, savings have gone from all-time highs to really, they're almost all gone. And so, you're going to see eventually, again --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: They're not --

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: -- credit card debt -- yes, go on.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. I was just -- delinquencies -- credit card delinquencies are a -- it sounds like what you're saying -- are lower. It sounds like what you're saying is we're on the precipice maybe, right? Because Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan was warning about this -- what happens in a year or so when all -- when all those -- that excess savings is gone.Is that what you're worried about?

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm worried about that. I'm worried about that many cars now -- we have almost the highest repossession in cars than we've had in a long time. We have over 250,000 people who bought homes that are now underwater. We have a million people that only have 10 percent equity in their homes.So, we have a situation where, yes, people may be going out, people may be doing things --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: -- but they're still living paycheck to paycheck. And that is a big warning sign in my book. People need to be careful.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So let's get to your advice because folks write you, they come on the podcast, they ask you all of these questions. Quickly, let's tick through a few.If someone asked you right now if they should sell their home?

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: I would say if they want to move -- they're not going to stay in their home -- I would sell it sooner than later. You bet I would.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What about a car -- for persons thinking about an optional car purchase, not something urgent?

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. If you're going to buy a car and you cannot afford to buy a car outright -- really, everybody, don't buy a brand-new car. Buy a used car. Because the second you drive a car off the lot --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: -- it depreciates 24 (PH) percent. So, used car prices are finally coming down.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's good.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: But if it's an optional purchase, just wait. Don't do it right now. They're going to get cheaper.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Don is sitting over here nodding and giving you a thumbs up. Because I've never bought a new car.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, Don. Yes, Don.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I've never bought a new car.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I see her.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I have a -- I have a 2010 Toyota. I've always bought a used car. I totally agree with you.Quickly, before you go, though, I think yesterday in the announcement from the Fed chair and the rate announcement that it sort of is getting glossed over that the Fed did say unemployment, they think, will tick up to 4.6 percent, and that would mean a million more jobs lost in like a year.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, and --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's a lot of pain.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thoughts? Christine Romans is here with us, too -- guys?

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: In a high-interest-rate-environment you've got to be paying down that high-interest debt. Be so careful of the -- and, you know, Suze, credit card interest rates are record highs. And those store credit cards -- I know you hate these like I do. These store credit cards, 29 percent -- HARLOW

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: -- for these store credit cards. I mean, it seems to me like it's a sign --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I never open them, ever.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's easy. Don't do it.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: -- of distress.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Don't do it.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: A sign of financial distress if you're -- if you're getting all these cards with these high interest rates.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, and it's not only that. It's also home equity lines of credit. A lot of people are moving now from -- once they've maxed out credit cards or whatever -- let's take out a home equity line of credit. We have 70 percent equity in our homes or whatever it may be. Remember, when rates go up, your home equity line of credit is going to skyrocket.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: So, everybody, let's come back to Earth. If you don't have the cash to pay for it, don't buy it.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Suze.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We are on Earth thanks to you. Thank you, Suze.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Hi to K.T., Suze.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Be well. Merry Christmas to you.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, love to Tim. Bye-bye.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Happy holidays.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you. You as well.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: All right. That was so helpful.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Does a 1987 station wagon count as a used car?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Oh -- because you get like --(Crosstalk)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Don gets, like, fancy used cars. I'm like old Toyota. There is new data this morning on when cancer is being detected and diagnosed in the United States. Why it left the author of this study shocked.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Well, this morning, the entertainment world is mourning the loss of the "THE ELLEN SHOW" deejay Stephen Boss. And you may also know him as Twitch. The L.A. County medical examiner confirmed that he died by suicide.Twitch rose to fame on the fourth season of "SO YOU THINK YOU CAN DANCE" where he was a runner-up. He would later go on to deejay for "THE ELLEN DEGENERES SHOW." In an Instagram post, the former daytime host wrote this. "I'm heartbroken. Twitch was pure love and light. He was my family and I loved him with all my heart." DeGeneres paid tribute to her deejay in one of the final episodes of the series. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) ELLEN DEGENERES, HOST, "THE ELLEN DEGENERES SHOW":  I love you like crazy.

utterances.speaker: BOSS
utterances.sentences: I love (crying) -- I'm sorry. I was not prepared. I love you and also, I love the family that we've gained here. And something that I'll always remember is that you gave me a place where I could just be myself.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Twitch was just 40 years old.Joining us now is Dr. Jodi Gold. She's the director of the Gold Center For Mind Health Wellness. Thank you for joining us. This is really sad and -- but it's a -- it's an opportunity, sadly, to talk about these issues and to get people to understand it more. You just don't know. It's hiding in plain sight most of the time. DR. JODI GOLD, DIRECTOR, GOLD CENTER FOR MIND HEALTH WELLNESS:  Yes, that's the truth. The truth is we have a hidden epidemic of mental health and it's hiding in plain sight. And I think that deejay Twitch's suicide is just a reminder of that because I think his public persona was such a happy, positive persona that maybe we didn't know. But the truth is that sometimes we just don't ask.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So can we talk about that?

utterances.speaker: GOLD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Like, we don't go to brunch with our friends -- I mean, we go deep on things but how often do we actually say, like, are you OK? We've been talking about --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. But usually, people don't say I'm OK but -- or I'm thinking about suicide. They just don't do that, right?

utterances.speaker: GOLD
utterances.sentences: Right, they don't. And we do check in with our friends but the truth is we don't often ask about suicide.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Ah.

utterances.speaker: GOLD
utterances.sentences: The truth is that one in 10 adults and one in five teenagers think seriously about suicide.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: GOLD
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's that prevalent.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Twenty percent of teens?

utterances.speaker: GOLD
utterances.sentences: Twenty percent of teens have thought seriously about suicide. There is a suicide once every 11 minutes. So this is real, the fact that suicide happens, but it doesn't have to happen. And I think that there's been an increased awareness like the pandemic, and there's the surgeon general's warning that there's a mental health crisis for kids. And we know that up to a third of kids and adults with depression don't get the treatment they need.But what's so striking about this is that he seemed like he had everything, right? And the truth is that you to ask. Now, we don't know about his personal life and all of that, but it does bring up the conversation about the conversation do we ask enough? Do we screen enough?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And I feel like one thing that I've noticed is -- I'm 30. I feel like people my age and younger -- they're way more open in talking about their mental health. I think that people who are --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And my friends don't.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- older generations --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Isn't that interesting?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- they don't talk -- HARLOW

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- about it as much.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And I wonder how much that factors into this -- like, just not talking about it -- what Don was saying.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What are -- what should we ask?

utterances.speaker: GOLD
utterances.sentences: It's like have you been thinking about life not being worth living? Are you feeling hopeless? Are you alone? And I realize that's not super fun. It doesn't roll off the tongue.But if you're worried about someone, that's the way you get -- I mean, you'd be surprised when I ask those questions how much people will answer no, I actually need help or I've been thinking about it. And then, there's help out there. I mean, I think that's part of the discussion as well, right? There's an increase in screening. We have -- we have suicide hotlines that you can call, which is wonderful. We still need more screening and we still -- and on a more global level need better treatment.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GOLD
utterances.sentences: Do you know that like every state in this country is a -- doesn't have enough child psychiatrists? And that 70 percent of our country doesn't -- has a deficit in mental health providers.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's just the numbers are awful.

utterances.speaker: GOLD
utterances.sentences: They're -- yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But it is an important conversation to have, so thank you for joining us to have that conversation this morning, Dr. Gold. GOLD

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you.
